ul: Android applications that open saved files or documents.

Canonicalize File Names and Paths
 Validate All Input
 Validate and Encode Data Inserted into XML Documents
 Validate File Formats

File Names and Paths Are Canonicalized
 All Input Is Validated
 Data Inserted into XML Documents Is Validated and Encoded
 File Formats Are Validated
li: Android applications that open saved files or documents.

Define the file format. Specify valid values for all possible fields in all document types used by your applications. This information should be a part of project documentation and the developers may already have it.

Review code. Search for code that loads saved files into the application. Examine the extents of the validation already being performed by the application. If some validation is already being performed, some code may be recycled for a more thorough validation routine.
Implement validation. Write validation functions for all fields in all document types supported by the application.

Centralize validation. Move the validation functions for all document fields to the centralized input and data validation class or library. Write a master file format validation function that calls all individual data field validation functions.

Use validation. Go back to code that loads data files into the application. Remove any old validation code. Add code that calls the master file format validation function on all files being loaded before loading them into the application.
Validate and Encode Data Inserted into XML Documents
File Names and Paths Are Canonicalized
Data Inserted into XML Documents Is Validated and Encoded
p: Verify that file formats are validated.

Many vulnerabilities are exploited via malformed documents supplied to the application. One particular vector of attack that is frequently used is embedding malformed documents in web pages - some applications are integrated into the web browser and will open malicious documents automatically in that scenario. Making sure that file format is valid before loading files into the application makes it harder to embed exploit code into documents.
Identify the functions that open data files. Verify that these functions include provisions for validating the input data file format before passing it on to other functions.
Perform the following actions to validate file format before loading files into the application:
ol:
Define the file format. Specify valid values for all possible fields in all document types used by your applications. This information should be a part of project documentation and the developers may already have it.
 Review code. Search for code that loads saved files into the application. Examine the extents of the validation already being performed by the application. If some validation is already being performed, some code may be recycled for a more thorough validation routine.
 Implement validation. Write validation functions for all fields in all document types supported by the application.
 Centralize validation. Move the validation functions for all document fields to the centralized input and data validation class or library. Write a master file format validation function that calls all individual data field validation functions.
 Use validation. Go back to code that loads data files into the application. Remove any old validation code. Add code that calls the master file format validation function on all files being loaded before loading them into the application.
a: Validate and Encode Data Inserted into XML Documents
File Names and Paths Are Canonicalized
Data Inserted into XML Documents Is Validated and Encoded

links.text: Validate and Encode Data Inserted into XML Documents
File Names and Paths Are Canonicalized
Data Inserted into XML Documents Is Validated and Encoded

html:
Applies To

  • Android applications that open saved files or documents.

What to Check For

Verify that file formats are validated.

Why

Many vulnerabilities are exploited via malformed documents supplied to the application. One particular vector of attack that is frequently used is embedding malformed documents in web pages - some applications are integrated into the web browser and will open malicious documents automatically in that scenario. Making sure that file format is valid before loading files into the application makes it harder to embed exploit code into documents.

How to Check

Identify the functions that open data files. Verify that these functions include provisions for validating the input data file format before passing it on to other functions.

How to Fix

Perform the following actions to validate file format before loading files into the application:

  1. Define the file format. Specify valid values for all possible fields in all document types used by your applications. This information should be a part of project documentation and the developers may already have it.
  2. Review code. Search for code that loads saved files into the application. Examine the extents of the validation already being performed by the application. If some validation is already being performed, some code may be recycled for a more thorough validation routine.
  3. Implement validation. Write validation functions for all fields in all document types supported by the application.
  4. Centralize validation. Move the validation functions for all document fields to the centralized input and data validation class or library. Write a master file format validation function that calls all individual data field validation functions.
  5. Use validation. Go back to code that loads data files into the application. Remove any old validation code. Add code that calls the master file format validation function on all files being loaded before loading them into the application.

Data Validation Guidelines

  • Canonicalize File Names and Paths
  • Validate All Input
  • Validate and Encode Data Inserted into XML Documents
  • Validate File Formats

Data Validation Checklists

  • File Names and Paths Are Canonicalized
  • All Input Is Validated
  • Data Inserted into XML Documents Is Validated and Encoded
  • File Formats Are Validated
